questions.question_text: What period of radical political and societal upheaval in France began with the Estates General of 1789 and ended with Napoleon's Coup of 18 Brumaire in November 1799?

Which 1914-1918 conflict, triggered by the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand in Sarajevo, pitted the Allied Powers against the Central Powers and resulted in an estimated 30 million military casualties?
Which 1939-1945 global conflict, the deadliest in human history with over 60 million dead, ended with the Allied defeat of the Axis powers and the first use of nuclear weapons in warfare?
What ancient political entity, established when Octavian received the title Augustus from the Senate in 27 BC, dominated the Mediterranean world until the Western half collapsed in 476 AD?
What devastating 1346-1353 pandemic, caused by the bacterium Yersinia pestis and spread by fleas, killed as many as 50 million people, roughly half of Europe's population?

What European cultural movement, first centered in the Republic of Florence, marked the transition from the Middle Ages to modernity through a rediscovery of classical antiquity in art, literature, and science?
Which Corsica-born French general served as First Consul from 1799, crowned himself Emperor of the French in 1804, and was finally defeated at the Battle of Waterloo in 1815?
What genocide, known in Hebrew as the Shoah, saw Nazi Germany and its collaborators systematically murder approximately six million Jews in extermination camps and mass shootings from 1941 to 1945?

What period of geopolitical rivalry between the United States and the Soviet Union, expressed through proxy wars, a nuclear arms race, and the Space Race, ended with the dissolution of the USSR in 1991?
What northeastern Mediterranean civilization, organized into independent city-states such as Athens and Sparta, is widely regarded as the cradle of Western democracy, philosophy, and science?

What 16th-century religious movement, initiated when Martin Luther posted his Ninety-five Theses in 1517, permanently split Western Christianity by challenging Catholic doctrines such as the sale of indulgences?

On November 9, 1989, which Cold War barrier was unexpectedly opened after East German spokesman Gunter Schabowski announced new travel regulations, leading to jubilant crowds crossing freely between East and West?

What series of medieval religious wars, launched by Pope Urban II at the Council of Clermont in 1095, aimed to recapture the Holy Land from Muslim control and led to the temporary establishment of Christian states in the Levant?

What 1814-1815 diplomatic conference, chaired by Austrian statesman Klemens von Metternich, redrew European borders after Napoleon's defeat and established a balance-of-power system intended to preserve continental stability?
Which devastating 1618-1648 conflict, triggered by the Defenestration of Prague, engulfed much of Central Europe in religious and political warfare and ended with the Peace of Westphalia?

What 1215 royal charter, sealed by King John at Runnymede under pressure from rebel barons, established that the English monarch was subject to the rule of law and guaranteed rights such as protection from unlawful imprisonment?

What period of European maritime expansion, beginning in the 15th century, saw Portuguese navigators round the Cape of Good Hope and Vasco da Gama reach India by sea in 1498, while Spanish-funded Columbus crossed the Atlantic in 1492?

What 18th-century European intellectual movement championed reason and empirical science, produced Diderot and d'Alembert's Encyclopedie, and featured thinkers such as Voltaire and Rousseau who challenged traditional authority?

Which Prussian statesman, known for his 'blood and iron' speech of 1862, engineered three wars against Denmark, Austria, and France to achieve the unification of Germany, proclaimed as an empire at Versailles in January 1871?

What medieval empire, the eastern continuation of Rome centered on Constantinople, preserved Roman law through Justinian's Corpus Juris Civilis and endured until the Ottoman conquest of its capital in 1453?

Which article of the Treaty of Versailles, signed on 28 June 1919 in the Hall of Mirrors, required Germany to accept responsibility for causing all wartime losses and served as the legal basis for reparations?

options.A: Article 231, known as the war guilt clause
options.B: Article 428, known as the territorial occupation clause
options.C: Article 119, known as the colonial reparations clause
options.D: Article 159, known as the military disarmament clause

questions.question_text: What was the final major battle of the Hundred Years' War, fought on 17 July 1453 in Gascony, where French field artillery decisively defeated the English forces under the Earl of Shrewsbury?
In medieval European feudalism, what was the term for the grant of land a lord gave to a vassal in exchange for military service, loyalty, and other obligations?
During the October Revolution of 1917, which building in Petrograd did Bolshevik Red Guards storm to overthrow the Russian Provisional Government led by Alexander Kerensky?
Which Athenian historian and general wrote the primary contemporary account of the Peloponnesian War (431-404 BC) between Athens and Sparta, though his text ends abruptly in 411 BC?
Which 1884-1885 diplomatic meeting, organised by Otto von Bismarck, established rules for European claims to African territory during the Scramble for Africa, with no African representatives present?
The Peace of Westphalia (1648) comprised two treaties negotiated in separate Westphalian cities. Which two cities hosted the negotiations that ended the Thirty Years' War?
The Concert of Europe maintained a balance of power from 1815 to the mid-19th century through periodic congresses. Which five states constituted the 'great powers' in this diplomatic system?

options.A: Britain, Russia, Prussia, the Ottoman Empire, and France
options.B: Britain, Russia, Austria, Prussia, and France
options.C: Britain, Austria, Prussia, Sweden, and the Netherlands
options.D: Britain, Russia, Austria, Spain, and France

questions.question_text: Between 1760 and 1832, over 5,200 Parliamentary enclosure acts converted roughly one-fifth of England's total area from common land to private property. What major economic transformation did the resulting displacement of rural laborers help supply a workforce for?
The Revolutions of 1848, called the 'Spring of Nations,' began in Sicily and spread after which French king abdicated on 24 February 1848, leading to the proclamation of the Second Republic?

The Treaty of Verdun in 843 divided the Carolingian Empire among the three surviving sons of Emperor Louis the Pious. What were the three resulting kingdoms, and why is this partition considered a pivotal moment in European political geography?

options.A: It created Burgundy (future Switzerland), Aquitaine (future Spain), and Saxony (future Poland), establishing the borders that would define Eastern European nation-states.
options.B: It created Normandy (future England), Provence (future Spain), and Thuringia (future Netherlands), partitioning the empire according to linguistic boundaries.
options.C: It created West Francia (future France), East Francia (future Germany), and Middle Francia (Lotharingia/Italy), foreshadowing the formation of major modern Western European nation-states.
options.D: It created Lombardy (future Italy), Brittany (future France), and Bavaria (future Austria), dividing the empire along pre-existing Roman provincial boundaries.

questions.question_text: In 1896, Lieutenant Colonel Georges Picquart discovered evidence identifying the real spy in the Dreyfus Affair. Who was the actual traitor, and what happened when Picquart presented his findings to the French military high command?

options.A: The real spy was Major Ferdinand Walsin Esterhazy. The military suppressed Picquart's evidence, and a court-martial unanimously acquitted Esterhazy after a trial lasting only two days.
options.B: The real spy was General Raoul Le Mouton de Boisdeffre. The military transferred Picquart to a colonial post but reopened Dreyfus's case within months.
options.C: The real spy was Captain Marie-Charles Lauth. The military forwarded Picquart's findings to parliament, which launched an independent civilian investigation.
options.D: The real spy was Colonel Auguste Mercier. The military accepted Picquart's evidence immediately and quietly released Dreyfus without a public retrial.

questions.question_text: The Ottoman Empire was characterized as the 'sick man of Europe' during the 19th century. Which two great powers had the most directly opposing strategic interests regarding the Ottoman Empire's survival, and why?

options.A: Russia stood to gain from Ottoman decline by expanding toward the Mediterranean and protecting Orthodox Christians, while Britain sought to preserve the Ottoman Empire to block Russian expansion and protect its route to India.
options.B: France stood to gain from Ottoman decline by annexing North Africa, while Prussia sought to preserve the empire to maintain a buffer against Austrian expansion into the Balkans.
options.C: Austria-Hungary stood to gain from Ottoman decline by absorbing Balkan territories, while Italy sought to preserve the empire to prevent French dominance of the Mediterranean.
options.D: Germany stood to gain from Ottoman decline by controlling Middle Eastern oil resources, while Spain sought to preserve the empire to maintain its commercial trading privileges.

questions.question_text: The Weimar Republic experienced a period of relative stability and cultural flourishing between 1924 and 1929, sometimes called the 'Golden Twenties.' What international agreements helped produce this stabilization, and what ended it?

options.A: The Rapallo Treaty of 1925 secured a Franco-German military alliance, and Germany joined the Hague Court in 1926, but hyperinflation returned in 1929 when the Reichsbank collapsed.
options.B: The Locarno Treaties of 1925 normalized Germany's relations with its neighbors, and Germany joined the League of Nations in 1926, but the Great Depression of 1929 destroyed this progress by causing mass unemployment and political radicalization.
options.C: The Dawes Plan of 1925 eliminated Germany's war guilt clause, and Germany joined the Concert of Europe in 1926, but a series of political assassinations in 1929 destabilized the government.
options.D: The Kellogg-Briand Pact of 1925 ended all reparations payments, and Germany joined NATO in 1926, but the collapse of the British pound in 1929 triggered a European banking crisis.

questions.question_text: The Hanseatic League established major foreign trading posts called Kontors in non-member cities. In which four cities were these principal Kontors located, and what legal status did they enjoy?

options.A: The four principal Kontors were in Amsterdam (the Exchange), Hamburg, Copenhagen (Oresund), and Danzig (Langgasse). They served as customs-free zones governed by local municipal law.
options.B: The four principal Kontors were in London (the Steelyard), Bruges, Bergen (Bryggen), and Novgorod (Peterhof). They functioned as extraterritorial enclaves with considerable legal autonomy.
options.C: The four principal Kontors were in Paris (the Guildhall), Venice, Stockholm (Birka), and Kiev (Podil). They operated as diplomatic embassies with full sovereign immunity.
options.D: The four principal Kontors were in Antwerp (the Bourse), Cologne, Oslo (Bjorgvin), and Riga (Petrikirche). They functioned as joint-stock companies with royal charters from host monarchs.

questions.question_text: The Spanish Inquisition was originally established to investigate a specific group of people. Who were these primary targets, and how did the Inquisition's authority differ from that of the earlier Medieval Inquisition?

options.A: Its primary targets were Templars -- former crusader knights suspected of harboring heretical beliefs. Unlike the Medieval Inquisition, which operated through ecclesiastical courts, the Spanish Inquisition used secular military tribunals.
options.B: Its primary targets were conversos -- Jews who had converted to Christianity but were suspected of secretly practicing Judaism. Unlike the Medieval Inquisition, which was under papal control, the Spanish Inquisition operated under the authority of the Spanish Crown.
options.C: Its primary targets were Cathars -- Christian heretics who rejected the sacraments and Church hierarchy. Unlike the Medieval Inquisition, which answered to local bishops, the Spanish Inquisition reported directly to the Papal Curia in Rome.
options.D: Its primary targets were Waldensians -- followers of Peter Waldo who preached poverty and vernacular scripture. Unlike the Medieval Inquisition, which relied on Dominican investigators, the Spanish Inquisition used Franciscan friars exclusively.

questions.question_text: By 1870, only about 10 percent of Africa was under formal European control, but by 1914 this figure had risen to nearly 90 percent. Which two African states maintained their sovereignty throughout the Scramble for Africa, and what major international event formalized European rules for claiming African territory?

options.A: Morocco and Madagascar remained independent. The Congress of Brussels in 1876-1877, organized by Leopold II, established rules requiring bilateral treaties with indigenous rulers for territorial claims.
options.B: Ethiopia and Liberia remained independent. The Berlin Conference of 1884-1885, organized by Otto von Bismarck, established rules requiring 'effective occupation' for European claims to African territory.
options.C: Egypt and the Congo remained independent. The Paris Conference of 1882-1883, organized by Jules Ferry, established rules requiring military conquest before European claims could be recognized.
options.D: Tunisia and Zanzibar remained independent. The London Conference of 1880-1881, organized by Lord Salisbury, established rules requiring commercial development before formal annexation.

questions.question_text: The Decembrist revolt of 1825 exploited a dynastic confusion in the Russian succession. What was the source of this confusion, and what political system did the Northern Society conspirators seek to establish?

options.A: Grand Duke Konstantin had secretly renounced his claim to the throne, leaving his younger brother Nicholas as heir, but neither the public nor much of the military knew. The Northern Society sought to replace autocracy with a constitutional monarchy.
options.B: Grand Duke Nicholas had been exiled for plotting against Alexander I, making Konstantin the only eligible heir. The Northern Society sought to establish a theocratic state governed by the Russian Orthodox Church.
options.C: Emperor Alexander I had secretly designated a non-Romanov general as his successor, bypassing both his brothers entirely. The Northern Society sought to establish a military dictatorship modeled on Napoleonic France.
options.D: Emperor Alexander I had secretly converted to Catholicism, disqualifying him from the throne under Russian law. The Northern Society sought to establish a federated republic modeled on the United States.

questions.question_text: Diocletian's Edict on Maximum Prices of 301 AD was an ambitious attempt to address a major economic crisis in the Roman Empire. What problem was the Edict designed to solve, and why did it ultimately fail?

options.A: It attempted to eliminate tax evasion by fixing uniform tax rates across all provinces. It failed because provincial governors refused to enforce rates that reduced their personal revenue.
options.B: It attempted to curb rampant inflation by setting maximum prices for goods and services throughout the empire. It failed because it was counterproductive, patchily enforced, and largely ignored by the end of Diocletian's reign in 305.
options.C: It attempted to abolish the slave trade by setting minimum wages for free laborers. It failed because wealthy landowners circumvented it by reclassifying slaves as indentured servants.
options.D: It attempted to prevent currency debasement by standardizing the gold content of Roman coinage. It failed because gold supplies from Spanish mines were exhausted by 303 AD.

questions.question_text: The Investiture Controversy began in 1076 as a power struggle between Pope Gregory VII and King Henry IV. What dramatic confrontation between the two in 1077 became a defining symbol of papal authority over secular rulers during the medieval period?

options.A: Henry IV's Penance at Aachen, where the king crawled on his knees through the cathedral to kiss Gregory VII's ring and renounce imperial authority over Italian bishops.
options.B: Henry IV's Siege of the Lateran, where the king blockaded the papal palace in Rome for three weeks until Gregory VII agreed to crown him Holy Roman Emperor.
options.C: Henry IV's Oath at Augsburg, where the king publicly swore before German bishops to surrender all imperial lands north of the Alps to papal jurisdiction.
options.D: Henry IV's Walk to Canossa in January 1077, where the excommunicated king reportedly knelt for three days and nights before the castle gate during a blizzard, supplicating Pope Gregory VII to revoke his excommunication.

questions.question_text: The Annales school revolutionized historiography by rejecting political narrative in favor of long-term structural analysis. What was the journal's founding year and institutional home, and who were its two co-founders?

options.A: Founded in 1935 at the Collège de France by Henri Berr and Lucien Febvre, the journal emphasized cultural anthropology and mentalité studies over traditional institutional history.
options.B: Founded in 1919 at the Sorbonne by Fernand Braudel and Georges Duby, the journal emphasized quantitative demographic analysis over traditional diplomatic and military history.
options.C: Founded in 1929 at the École Normale Supérieure by Marc Bloch and Fernand Braudel, the journal emphasized comparative civilizational studies over traditional biographical narratives.
options.D: Founded in 1929 at the University of Strasbourg by Marc Bloch and Lucien Febvre, it emphasized economic, social, and geographical approaches over political narrative.

questions.question_text: The Dolchstoßlegende became central to German right-wing politics after 1918. Who publicly lent this myth credibility through testimony before a parliamentary inquiry committee in November 1919?

options.A: Chancellor Friedrich Ebert testified that the German home front had been 'sabotaged by Marxists,' using words drafted by Field Marshal August von Mackensen.
options.B: General Erich Ludendorff testified that the German navy had been 'betrayed from within,' using words drafted by Kaiser Wilhelm II before his abdication.
options.C: Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg testified that the German army had been 'stabbed in the back,' using words actually drafted by Erich Ludendorff.
options.D: General Hans von Seeckt testified that the German officer corps had been 'undermined by republicans,' using words drafted by Foreign Minister Walther Rathenau.

questions.question_text: The medieval concept of translatio imperii drew on biblical prophecy to legitimize successive empires. From which biblical text did Jerome derive the four-kingdom scheme underlying this doctrine?

options.A: Jerome's commentary on the Book of Ezekiel interpreted the four living creatures as representing Babylon, Egypt, Greece, and Persia in divine succession.
options.B: Jerome's commentary on the Book of Revelation interpreted the four horsemen as representing Egypt, Assyria, Persia, and Rome in apocalyptic succession.
options.C: Jerome's commentary on the Book of Isaiah interpreted the four winds as representing Carthage, Macedonia, Parthia, and Rome in prophetic succession.
options.D: Jerome's commentary on the Book of Daniel interpreted Nebuchadnezzar's dream of four metals as representing Babylon, Medo-Persia, Greece, and Rome in ordained succession.

questions.question_text: During the July Crisis of 1914, Austria-Hungary delivered a deliberately unacceptable ultimatum to Serbia. On what date was it delivered, and how did Serbia respond?

options.A: Delivered July 28, 1914 with a 24-hour deadline, Serbia rejected all demands outright and immediately ordered full military mobilization along its northern border.
options.B: Delivered July 23, 1914 with a 48-hour deadline, Serbia requested mediation from Russia and France while refusing to respond directly to any demands.
options.C: Delivered July 15, 1914 with a 72-hour deadline, Serbia accepted all demands unconditionally but Austria-Hungary declared war citing insufficient guarantees of compliance.
options.D: Delivered July 23, 1914 with a 48-hour deadline, Serbia accepted nearly all demands but rejected allowing Austrian officials to investigate on Serbian soil.

questions.question_text: Tiberius Gracchus's land reform in 133 BC provoked unprecedented political violence in the Roman Republic. What was the core provision of his lex agraria, and how was he killed?

options.A: His law abolished private land ownership, collectivizing farmland under state control. Consul Scaevola ordered his arrest, and he was executed after a Senate trial.
options.B: His law capped public land at 500 iugera per citizen, redistributing excess to the landless. Senators led by Scipio Nasica bludgeoned him on the Capitoline.
options.C: His law granted citizenship to Italian allies surrendering excess public land. A hired assassin sent by Scipio Aemilianus killed him during a public assembly.
options.D: His law taxed estates exceeding 1,000 iugera, funding grain subsidies for urban plebeians. He was poisoned at a banquet organized by the patrician faction.

questions.question_text: The Thermidorian Reaction ended the radical phase of the French Revolution. What governmental system replaced the Committee of Public Safety, and when did it take power?

options.A: The Constitution of Year II established the Consulate, a three-member executive body with a unicameral legislature, which assumed power on August 22, 1794.
options.B: The Constitution of Year III established the National Convention, a twelve-member executive council with a bicameral legislature, which assumed power on June 1, 1795.
options.C: The Constitution of Year III established the Directory, a five-member executive body with a bicameral legislature, which assumed power on November 2, 1795.
options.D: The Constitution of Year IV established the Tribunate, a seven-member executive body with a tricameral legislature, which assumed power on March 15, 1796.

questions.question_text: The Querelle des Anciens et des Modernes erupted publicly at the Académie française. What work ignited the controversy, who authored it, and what did it argue?

options.A: François Fénelon's 1694 dialogue Les Aventures de Télémaque declared Homer superior to modern epic poets, provoking Pierre Corneille's defense of French innovation.
options.B: Nicolas Boileau's 1674 treatise L'Art poétique declared French neoclassical drama superior to Greek tragedy, provoking Charles Perrault's defense of Aristotelian conventions.
options.C: Jean Racine's 1689 essay Parallèle des Anciens declared Euripides superior to all modern playwrights, provoking Bernard de Fontenelle's defense of scientific progress.
options.D: Charles Perrault's 1687 poem Le Siècle de Louis le Grand declared Louis XIV's era superior to antiquity, provoking Nicolas Boileau's defense of classical supremacy.

questions.source_article: Quarrel of the Ancients and the Moderns
concepts_tested: Querelle des Anciens et des Modernes

questions.question_text: The Eastern Front in World War I was far more fluid than the Western Front. What was the largest Allied offensive on this front, and what were its strategic consequences?

options.A: The Gorlice-Tarnów Offensive (May–July 1915) inflicted over one million casualties on the Ottoman Empire, crippling its Caucasus forces and forcing Bulgaria to seek an armistice.
options.B: The Brusilov Offensive (June–August 1916) inflicted over one million casualties on Austria-Hungary, crippling its military and forcing Germany to divert divisions from Verdun.
options.C: The Kerensky Offensive (July–September 1917) inflicted over one million casualties on Germany, crippling its Eastern reserves and forcing Austria-Hungary to withdraw from the Balkans.
options.D: The Lake Naroch Offensive (March–June 1916) inflicted over one million casualties on Austria-Hungary, crippling its Galician garrisons and forcing Germany to abandon the Somme campaign.

questions.question_text: The Sykes-Picot Agreement was a secret wartime pact that contradicted promises made to Arab allies. How was the agreement exposed, and what was the immediate diplomatic consequence?

options.A: Ottoman intelligence intercepted a diplomatic cable and published the text in Istanbul newspapers in March 1917, embarrassing France and triggering Arab revolt.
options.B: American journalists uncovered it in French ministry files and published the text in the New York Times in January 1918, embarrassing both powers and prompting negotiations.
options.C: British parliamentary critics leaked it to the Manchester Guardian in September 1916, embarrassing the Foreign Office and forcing Sir Edward Grey's resignation.
options.D: The Bolsheviks found it in Tsarist archives and published the text in Izvestia and Pravda in November 1917, embarrassing Britain and deepening Arab distrust.

questions.question_text: Henri Pirenne's thesis challenged the traditional narrative of Western civilization's origins. What did he argue caused the real break with classical antiquity, and what famous formulation summarized his argument?

options.A: Pirenne argued the Plague of Justinian, not Germanic migrations, ended Roman demographic stability and created medieval Europe. His famous dictum: 'Without pestilence, the Dark Ages would be inconceivable.'
options.B: Pirenne argued Islamic expansion, not Germanic invasions, ended Mediterranean unity and created medieval Europe. His famous dictum: 'Without Muhammad, Charlemagne would be inconceivable.'
options.C: Pirenne argued Byzantine bureaucratic decline, not barbarian conquest, ended Roman governance and created feudal Europe. His famous dictum: 'Without Justinian, the Carolingians would be inconceivable.'
options.D: Pirenne argued climatic deterioration, not military invasion, ended Roman agricultural systems and created medieval Europe. His famous dictum: 'Without the Little Ice Age, feudalism would be inconceivable.'
